sendaman69 wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> I have two question regarding Heritrix 2:
> 
> 1.) How do I request a crawl stop in a processor (innerProcess())?
> 
> I found the method requestCrawlStop() in the CrawlController but wasn't able to find out how I get to my CrawlController inside of a processor's innerProcess() method!?

If you're just starting to work with the Heritrix codebase, I recommend 
you use the latest Heritrix 1.x version (the released code which is 
best-documented and most-used). If you are forward-looking and 
adventurous, you could start with the pre-release Heritrix 3.x code.

In Heritrix 1, class Processor has a method getController() which will 
give you the CrawlController. You can see an example of a use similar to 
yours in LowDiskPauseProcessor -- a processor that pauses the crawl. 
(LowDiskPauseProcessor uses a different mechanism in H2.x, and seems to 
be doing something slightly wrong with the URI-in-progress when the 
pause is triggered.)

(In Heritrix 3, which uses the popular Spring framework to configure 
crawls using the 'Inversion of Control' style, if your processor bean as 
requires a CrawlController instance at construction time, it will be 
automatically supplied by the automatic 'wiring'.)

> ----------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> 2.) I have a list which I instantiate in the initialTasks() method of one of my processors and I would like to make sure that this list is only accessed by one toethread at a time (in the innerProcess() method of the referring processor of the toethread). How can I make sure that this list is only accessed by one toethread at a time?
> 
> I'm not really solid in multhithreading and this is kinda new problem to me. I looked into wait() and notify() methods and some general stuff but couldn't really figure something for Heritrix so I would appreciate any help on this!

The most simple way to achieve this would be to mark your local override 
of the innerProcess() method be 'synchronized'. Only one instance of 
your Processor is created, and 'synchronized' only allows one thread to 
enter any code which is 'synchronized' on that Processor instance at a 
time.

If you need a more sophisticated understanding of your options, you 
should consult a general Java reference on these topics.

- Gordon @ IA
